oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Port Royal State Park: Trail of Tears site marker
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: State Highway 238 at Old Clarksville-Springfield Rd.

Color photograph of a red road sign. White letters read "Trail of Tears original route; Fort Cass (Charleston), TN 197 miles; Woodhall's Depot (Westville), OK 546 miles". The old roadbed is visible in background

Port Royal was an early trading center because of its location at the junction of the Red River and Sulfur
Fork. The earliest settlers arrived in 1784 and the town, named by the Samuel Wilcox family, incorporated
in 1797. The first post office was established in 1801. The Port Royal site represents the importance
of river transportation in early Tennessee history. The Port Royal Historic State Park was established in 1978 to preserve and protect the history of the early river town. The park is also designated as site on the Trail of
Tears National Historic Trail.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Port Royal (Tenn.); Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Historical markers
